Document ID: 3163
Title: An Optimal Insertion Algorithm for One-Sided Height-Balanced BInary Search Trees
Text: An algorithm for inserting an element into a one-sided height-balanced (OSHB) binary search tree is presented.  The algorithm operates in time  O(log n), where n is the number of nodes in the tree.  This represents an improvement over the best previous ly known insertion algorithms of Hirschberg and Kosaraju, which require time O(log 2n).  Moreover, the O(log n) complexity is optimal. Earlier  results have shown that deletion in such a structure can also be performed in O(log n) time.  Thus the result of this paper gives a negative answer to the question of whether such trees should be the first examples of their kind, where deletion has a smaller time  complexity than insertion.  Furthermore, it can now be concluded that insertion, deletion, and retrieval in OSHB trees can be performed in the same time as the corresponding operations for the more general AVL trees, to within a constant factor.  However, the insertion and deletion algorithms for OSHB trees appear much more complicated than the corresponding algorithms for AVL trees.
Terms: ['', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '2n', 'a', 'a', 'a', 'a', 'a', 'algorithm', 'algorithm', 'algorithms', 'algorithms', 'algorithms', 'also', 'an', 'an', 'an', 'and', 'and', 'and', 'answer', 'appear', 'as', 'avl', 'avl', 'be', 'be', 'be', 'be', 'best', 'binary', 'can', 'can', 'can', 'complexity', 'complexity', 'complicated', 'concluded', 'constant', 'corresponding', 'corresponding', 'deletion', 'deletion', 'deletion', 'deletion', 'earlier', 'element', 'examples', 'factor', 'first', 'for', 'for', 'for', 'for', 'furthermore', 'general', 'gives', 'has', 'have', 'heightbalanced', 'hirschberg', 'however', 'improvement', 'in', 'in', 'in', 'in', 'in', 'in', 'inserting', 'insertion', 'insertion', 'insertion', 'insertion', 'into', 'is', 'is', 'is', 'it', 'kind', 'known', 'kosaraju', 'log', 'log', 'log', 'log', 'ly', 'more', 'more', 'moreover', 'much', 'n', 'n', 'n', 'n', 'negative', 'nodes', 'now', 'number', 'o', 'o', 'o', 'o', 'of', 'of', 'of', 'of', 'of', 'onesided', 'operates', 'operations', 'optimal', 'oshb', 'oshb', 'oshb', 'over', 'paper', 'performed', 'performed', 'presented', 'previous', 'question', 'represents', 'require', 'result', 'results', 'retrieval', 'same', 'search', 'should', 'shown', 'smaller', 'structure', 'such', 'such', 'than', 'than', 'that', 'that', 'the', 'the', 'the', 'the', 'the', 'the', 'the', 'the', 'the', 'the', 'the', 'the', 'the', 'their', 'this', 'this', 'thus', 'time', 'time', 'time', 'time', 'time', 'to', 'to', 'tree', 'tree', 'trees', 'trees', 'trees', 'trees', 'trees', 'where', 'where', 'whether', 'which', 'within']

Document ID: 3164
Title: Progressive Acyclic Digraphs-A Tool for Database Integrity
Text: A progressive acyclic digraph (PAD) algorithm accepts are requests and maintains a graph in an acyclic state.  When a request creates a cycle, nodes are, "detached" until the new are can be entered acyclically This process is important in certain areas of database implementation in which there are constraints on the permissible sequences of actions. Two PAD algorithms are presented; one uses a simple path matrix representation and the other uses a list with an "artificial gradient."  Experiments suggest that for large N the second is considerably faster, though both are asymptotically O(NR), where N is the number of nodes and R is the expected number of nodes reachable along paths from any given node.
Terms: ['', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', 'a', 'a', 'a', 'a', 'a', 'a', 'accepts', 'actions', 'acyclic', 'acyclic', 'acyclically', 'algorithm', 'algorithms', 'along', 'an', 'an', 'and', 'and', 'and', 'any', 'are', 'are', 'are', 'are', 'are', 'are', 'areas', 'artificial', 'asymptotically', 'be', 'both', 'can', 'certain', 'considerably', 'constraints', 'creates', 'cycle', 'database', 'detached', 'digraph', 'entered', 'expected', 'experiments', 'faster', 'for', 'from', 'given', 'gradient', 'graph', 'implementation', 'important', 'in', 'in', 'in', 'is', 'is', 'is', 'is', 'large', 'list', 'maintains', 'matrix', 'n', 'n', 'new', 'node', 'nodes', 'nodes', 'nodes', 'nr', 'number', 'number', 'o', 'of', 'of', 'of', 'of', 'on', 'one', 'other', 'pad', 'pad', 'path', 'paths', 'permissible', 'presented', 'process', 'progressive', 'r', 'reachable', 'representation', 'request', 'requests', 'second', 'sequences', 'simple', 'state', 'suggest', 'that', 'the', 'the', 'the', 'the', 'the', 'the', 'there', 'this', 'though', 'two', 'until', 'uses', 'uses', 'when', 'where', 'which', 'with']

Document ID: 3165
Title: Approximation of Polygonal Maps by Cellular Maps
Text: The approximation of polygonal thematic maps by cellular maps, an important operation in geographical data processing, is analyzed.  The data organization used for representing the polygonal maps is a widely used segment-based data structure, where class labels identify the regions bordering each segment on either side. The approximation algorithm presented operates on such an organization, eliminating the need for the recognition of region boundaries. Each segment is examined only once.  The versatility of the new organization is further illustrated by the outline of algorithms for area computation and point inclusion.  The algorithm is applied to a set of soil maps converted to computer-readable form by means of a coordinate digitizer.

Document ID: 3166
Title: Computing Standard Deviations: Accuracy
Text: Four algorithms for the numerical computation of the standard deviation of (unweighted) sampled data are analyzed.  Two of the algorithms are well-known in the statistical and computational literature; the other two are new algorithms specifically intended for automatic computation.  Our discussion is  expository, with emphasis on reaching a suitable definition of "accuracy."  Each of the four algorithms is analyzed for the conditions under which it will be accurate.  We conclude that all four algorithms will provide accurate answers for many problems, but two of the algorithms, one new, one old, are substantially more accurate on difficult problems than are the other two.
Terms: ['', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', 'a', 'accuracy', 'accurate', 'accurate', 'accurate', 'algorithms', 'algorithms', 'algorithms', 'algorithms', 'algorithms', 'algorithms', 'all', 'analyzed', 'analyzed', 'and', 'answers', 'are', 'are', 'are', 'are', 'are', 'automatic', 'be', 'but', 'computation', 'computation', 'computational', 'conclude', 'conditions', 'data', 'definition', 'deviation', 'difficult', 'discussion', 'each', 'emphasis', 'expository', 'for', 'for', 'for', 'for', 'four', 'four', 'four', 'in', 'intended', 'is', 'is', 'it', 'literature', 'many', 'more', 'new', 'new', 'numerical', 'of', 'of', 'of', 'of', 'of', 'of', 'old', 'on', 'on', 'one', 'one', 'other', 'other', 'our', 'problems', 'problems', 'provide', 'reaching', 'sampled', 'specifically', 'standard', 'statistical', 'substantially', 'suitable', 'than', 'that', 'the', 'the', 'the', 'the', 'the', 'the', 'the', 'the', 'the', 'two', 'two', 'two', 'two', 'under', 'unweighted', 'we', 'wellknown', 'which', 'will', 'will', 'with']

Document ID: 3172
Title: An Algorithm for Planning Collision-Free Paths Among Polyhedral Obstacles
Text: This paper describes a collision avoidance algorithm for planning a safe path for a polyhedral object moving among known polyhedral objects.  The algorithm transforms the obstacles so that they represent the locus of forbidden positions for an arbitrary reference point on the moving object.  A trajectory of this reference point which avoids all forbidden regions is free of collisions. Trajectories are found by searching a network which indicates, for each vertex  in the transformed obstacles, which other vertices can be reached safely.
Terms: ['', '', '', '', '', '', 'a', 'a', 'a', 'a', 'a', 'algorithm', 'algorithm', 'all', 'among', 'an', 'arbitrary', 'are', 'avoidance', 'avoids', 'be', 'by', 'can', 'collision', 'collisions', 'describes', 'each', 'for', 'for', 'for', 'for', 'forbidden', 'forbidden', 'found', 'free', 'in', 'indicates', 'is', 'known', 'locus', 'moving', 'moving', 'network', 'object', 'object', 'objects', 'obstacles', 'obstacles', 'of', 'of', 'of', 'on', 'other', 'paper', 'path', 'planning', 'point', 'point', 'polyhedral', 'polyhedral', 'positions', 'reached', 'reference', 'reference', 'regions', 'represent', 'safe', 'safely', 'searching', 'so', 'that', 'the', 'the', 'the', 'the', 'the', 'they', 'this', 'this', 'trajectories', 'trajectory', 'transformed', 'transforms', 'vertex', 'vertices', 'which', 'which', 'which']

Document ID: 3173
Title: A Psychology of Learning BASIC
Text: This paper addresses the question: What does a person know following learning of BASIC programming?  Several underlying conceptual structures are identified: (1) a transaction is an event that occurs in the computer and involves some operation on some object at some location, (2) a prestatement is a set of transactions corresponding to a line of code, (3) chunks are frequently occurring  configurations of prestatements corresponding to several lines of code.
Terms: ['', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '1', '2', '3', 'a', 'a', 'a', 'a', 'a', 'addresses', 'an', 'and', 'are', 'are', 'at', 'basic', 'chunks', 'code', 'code', 'computer', 'conceptual', 'configurations', 'corresponding', 'corresponding', 'does', 'event', 'following', 'frequently', 'identified', 'in', 'involves', 'is', 'is', 'know', 'learning', 'line', 'lines', 'location', 'object', 'occurring', 'occurs', 'of', 'of', 'of', 'of', 'of', 'on', 'operation', 'paper', 'person', 'prestatement', 'prestatements', 'programming', 'question', 'set', 'several', 'several', 'some', 'some', 'some', 'structures', 'that', 'the', 'the', 'this', 'to', 'to', 'transaction', 'transactions', 'underlying', 'what']

Document ID: 3174
Title: Password Security: A Case History
Text: This paper describes the history of the design of the password security scheme on a remotely accessed time-sharing system. The present design was the result of countering observed attempts to penetrate the system.  The result is a compromise between extreme security and ease of use.
Terms: ['', '', '', 'a', 'a', 'accessed', 'and', 'attempts', 'between', 'compromise', 'countering', 'describes', 'design', 'design', 'ease', 'extreme', 'history', 'is', 'observed', 'of', 'of', 'of', 'of', 'on', 'paper', 'password', 'penetrate', 'present', 'remotely', 'result', 'result', 'scheme', 'security', 'security', 'system', 'system', 'the', 'the', 'the', 'the', 'the', 'the', 'the', 'this', 'timesharing', 'to', 'use', 'was']

Document ID: 3175
Title: Breaking Substitution Ciphers Using a Relaxation Algorithm
Text: Substitution ciphers are codes in which each letter of the alphabet has one fixed substitute, and the word divisions  do not change.  In this paper the problem of breaking substitution ciphers is represented as a probabilistic labeling problem. Every code letter is assigned probabilities of representing plain text letters.  These probabilities are updated in parallel for all code letters, using joint letter probabilities.  Iterating the updating scheme results in improved estimates that finally lead to breaking the cipher.  The method is applies successfully to two examples.
Terms: ['', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', 'a', 'all', 'alphabet', 'and', 'applies', 'are', 'are', 'as', 'assigned', 'breaking', 'breaking', 'change', 'cipher', 'ciphers', 'ciphers', 'code', 'code', 'codes', 'divisions', 'do', 'each', 'estimates', 'every', 'examples', 'finally', 'fixed', 'for', 'has', 'improved', 'in', 'in', 'in', 'in', 'is', 'is', 'is', 'iterating', 'joint', 'labeling', 'lead', 'letter', 'letter', 'letter', 'letters', 'letters', 'method', 'not', 'of', 'of', 'of', 'one', 'paper', 'parallel', 'plain', 'probabilistic', 'probabilities', 'probabilities', 'probabilities', 'problem', 'problem', 'represented', 'representing', 'results', 'scheme', 'substitute', 'substitution', 'substitution', 'successfully', 'text', 'that', 'the', 'the', 'the', 'the', 'the', 'the', 'these', 'this', 'to', 'to', 'two', 'updated', 'updating', 'using', 'which', 'word']

Document ID: 3176
Title: Storing a Sparse Table
Text: The problem of storing and searching large sparse tables is ubiquitous in  computer science.  The standard technique for storing such tables is hashing, but hashing has poor worst-case performance.  We propose a good worst-case method for storing a static table of n entries, each an integer between 0 and N - 1.  The method requires 0(n) w words of storage and allows O(logn N) access time.  Although our method is a little complicated to use in practice, our analysis shows why a simpler algorithm used for compressing LR parsing tables works so well.
Terms: ['', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '0', '0', '1', 'a', 'a', 'a', 'a', 'access', 'algorithm', 'allows', 'although', 'an', 'analysis', 'and', 'and', 'and', 'between', 'but', 'complicated', 'compressing', 'computer', 'each', 'entries', 'for', 'for', 'for', 'good', 'has', 'hashing', 'hashing', 'in', 'in', 'integer', 'is', 'is', 'is', 'large', 'little', 'logn', 'lr', 'method', 'method', 'method', 'n', 'n', 'n', 'n', 'o', 'of', 'of', 'of', 'our', 'our', 'parsing', 'performance', 'poor', 'practice', 'problem', 'propose', 'requires', 'science', 'searching', 'shows', 'simpler', 'so', 'sparse', 'standard', 'static', 'storage', 'storing', 'storing', 'storing', 'such', 'table', 'tables', 'tables', 'tables', 'technique', 'the', 'the', 'the', 'time', 'to', 'ubiquitous', 'use', 'used', 'w', 'we', 'well', 'why', 'words', 'works', 'worstcase', 'worstcase']

Document ID: 3177
Title: How to Share a Secret
Text: In this paper we show how to divide data D into n pieces in such a way that D is easily reconstructable from any k pieces, but even complete knowledge of k - 1 pieces reveals olutely no information about D.  This technique enables the construction of robust key management schemes for cryptographic systems that can function securely and reliably even when misfortunes destroy half the pieces and security breaches expose all but one of the remaining pieces.
Terms: ['', '', '', '1', 'a', 'about', 'all', 'and', 'and', 'any', 'breaches', 'but', 'but', 'can', 'complete', 'construction', 'cryptographic', 'd', 'd', 'd', 'data', 'destroy', 'divide', 'easily', 'enables', 'even', 'even', 'expose', 'for', 'from', 'function', 'half', 'how', 'in', 'in', 'information', 'into', 'is', 'k', 'k', 'key', 'knowledge', 'management', 'misfortunes', 'n', 'no', 'of', 'of', 'of', 'olutely', 'one', 'paper', 'pieces', 'pieces', 'pieces', 'pieces', 'pieces', 'reconstructable', 'reliably', 'remaining', 'reveals', 'robust', 'schemes', 'securely', 'security', 'show', 'such', 'systems', 'technique', 'that', 'that', 'the', 'the', 'the', 'this', 'this', 'to', 'way', 'we', 'when']

Document ID: 3179
Title: Overview of the EFT Symposium
Text: It is increasingly recognized that large-scale technologies such as EFT have the potential for aiding in the solution of current societal problems. Yet, these technologies also generate problems.  This symposium presents selected papers from a conference that sought to discover what is currently known about EFT impacts in society and what research is needed in the future.

Document ID: 3180
Title: Costs of the Current U.S. Payments System
Text: Neither the banking industry nor public policy makers have good information on the comparative costs of alternative payment systems such as cash, checks, credit cards, and EFT transactions.  As a result, EFT systems and services are likely to be implemented without a valid assessment of whether they are cost-justified, lst alone justified in terms of other criteria.

Document ID: 3181
Title: Public Protection and Education with EFT
Text: Research has revealed the existence of widespread misinformation and lack of knowledge about EFT among business and government as well as consumers.  As a result, any effort to stimulate meaningful public participation in decisions on the introduction of EFT systems will require a coordinated educational effort of considerable scale.  In addition, research has revealed  shortcomings in the present system for defining responsibilities, liabilities, and avenues of recourse.  THis article presents several possible alternatives for improving the current system, but ongoing research is also needed to assure that actions taken will be responsive to the changing environment and consumer needs.
Terms: ['', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', 'a', 'a', 'about', 'actions', 'addition', 'also', 'alternatives', 'among', 'and', 'and', 'and', 'and', 'any', 'article', 'as', 'as', 'as', 'assure', 'avenues', 'be', 'business', 'but', 'changing', 'considerable', 'consumer', 'consumers', 'coordinated', 'current', 'decisions', 'defining', 'educational', 'effort', 'effort', 'eft', 'eft', 'environment', 'existence', 'for', 'for', 'government', 'has', 'has', 'improving', 'in', 'in', 'in', 'introduction', 'is', 'knowledge', 'lack', 'liabilities', 'meaningful', 'misinformation', 'needed', 'needs', 'of', 'of', 'of', 'of', 'of', 'on', 'ongoing', 'participation', 'possible', 'present', 'presents', 'public', 'recourse', 'require', 'research', 'research', 'research', 'responsibilities', 'responsive', 'result', 'revealed', 'revealed', 'scale', 'several', 'shortcomings', 'stimulate', 'system', 'system', 'systems', 'taken', 'that', 'the', 'the', 'the', 'the', 'the', 'this', 'to', 'to', 'to', 'well', 'widespread', 'will', 'will']

Document ID: 3182
Title: Vulnerabilities of EFTs to Intentionally Caused Losses
Text: The hypothesis that consumers are provided greater accuracy and freedom from error and fraud with electronic funds transfer systems (EFTs) is discussed in light of the technical capabilities and potential of the computer to protect against both accidentally and intentionally caused losses. Although the nomenclature for business crimes remains the same as for manual depository and other financial service systems - for example,  fraud, theft, embezzlement - the characteristics of the crimes are new. The changes resulting from the accelerating use of EFTs and  its continual technological advances broaden the scope of security issues to be examined.  Factors such as backup requirements,  regulatory and legislative actions, and economics give rise to the urgency for immediate research into solutions for emerging EFTs - related vulnerabilities.
Terms: ['', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', 'accelerating', 'accidentally', 'accuracy', 'actions', 'advances', 'against', 'although', 'and', 'and', 'and', 'and', 'and', 'and', 'and', 'and', 'are', 'are', 'as', 'as', 'backup', 'be', 'both', 'broaden', 'business', 'capabilities', 'caused', 'changes', 'characteristics', 'computer', 'consumers', 'continual', 'crimes', 'crimes', 'depository', 'discussed', 'economics', 'efts', 'efts', 'efts', 'electronic', 'embezzlement', 'emerging', 'error', 'examined', 'example', 'factors', 'financial', 'for', 'for', 'for', 'for', 'for', 'fraud', 'fraud', 'freedom', 'from', 'from', 'funds', 'give', 'greater', 'hypothesis', 'immediate', 'in', 'intentionally', 'into', 'is', 'issues', 'its', 'legislative', 'light', 'losses', 'manual', 'new', 'nomenclature', 'of', 'of', 'of', 'of', 'of', 'other', 'potential', 'protect', 'provided', 'regulatory', 'related', 'remains', 'requirements', 'research', 'resulting', 'rise', 'same', 'scope', 'security', 'service', 'solutions', 'such', 'systems', 'systems', 'technical', 'technological', 'that', 'the', 'the', 'the', 'the', 'the', 'the', 'the', 'the', 'the', 'the', 'the', 'theft', 'to', 'to', 'to', 'transfer', 'urgency', 'use', 'vulnerabilities', 'with']

Document ID: 3183
Title: Policy, Values, and EFT Research: Anatomy of a Research Agenda
Text: There is an emerging recognition that EFT systems have the potential to vastly alter the payment and fund transfer system in American society. A number of forces and actors are involved in this evolution, and the values vary significantly depending on individual and institutional  perspectives. These value conflicts are highlighted in a six-part research agenda: technological issues in EFT, EFT impacts  on people, economic impact of EFT, regulation and control of EFT, and evaluating and monitoring EFT systems.

Title: Revised Report on the Algorithmic Language ALGOL 60
Text: The report gives a complete defining description of the international algorithmic language ALGOL 60. This is a language suitable for expressing  a large class of numerical processes in a form sufficiently concise for  direct automatic translation into the language of programmed automatic computers.

Title: An Algebraic Compiler for the FORTRAN Assembly Program
Text: An algebraic compiler has been written which may be added to the FORTRAN  Assembly Program. Document ID: 3199
Title: ALGEM - An Algebraic Manipulator
Text: ALGEM is a package of subprograms written in Slip, FORTRAN IV and MAP 7094  II to manipulate algebraic expressions. Algem's basic algebraic operations are  additions, subtractions, multiplications, division and exponentiation. It is  capable of handling any number of single letter variables, variable exponents,  and of finding the highest common factor of two polynomials. Also included are such functions as substitution, differentiation, determining coefficients of specified variables, solving a linear equation, basic I/O routines plus other special purpose and arithmetic routines. The major innovation of Algem over  other manipulators is the assignment of types to all expressions and the use  of a standard ordering procedure.
Terms: ['', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '7094', 'a', 'a', 'a', 'additions', 'algebraic', 'algebraic', 'algem', 'algem', 'algem', 'all', 'also', 'and', 'and', 'and', 'and', 'and', 'any', 'are', 'are', 'arithmetic', 'as', 'assignment', 'basic', 'basic', 'capable', 'coefficients', 'common', 'determining', 'differentiation', 'division', 'equation', 'exponentiation', 'exponents', 'expressions', 'expressions', 'factor', 'finding', 'fortran', 'functions', 'handling', 'highest', 'ii', 'in', 'included', 'innovation', 'io', 'is', 'is', 'is', 'it', 'iv', 'letter', 'linear', 'major', 'manipulate', 'manipulators', 'map', 'multiplications', 'number', 'of', 'of', 'of', 'of', 'of', 'of', 'of', 'of', 'of', 'operations', 'ordering', 'other', 'other', 'over', 'package', 'plus', 'polynomials', 'procedure', 'purpose', 'routines', 'routines', 's', 'single', 'slip', 'solving', 'special', 'specified', 'standard', 'subprograms', 'substitution', 'subtractions', 'such', 'the', 'the', 'the', 'the', 'to', 'to', 'two', 'types', 'use', 'variable', 'variables', 'variables', 'written']

Document ID: 3200
Title: A FORMAC Program for the Solution of Linear Boundary and Initial Value  Problems
Text: A computer program is described which has been developed for obtaining approximate solutions to linear initial and boundary-value problems involving  differential equations. For each problem, input to the program includes:    1. The equations (in symbolic form) to be satisfied  -  the differential equations, equations describing auxiliary conditions such as boundary  conditions, etc.    2. A numerical description of the regions in which each of the equations are to be satisfied.    3. Sets of functions (in symbolic form) to be used in linear combinations to approximate the solution functions. Give the above input, the program generates an approximation to the solutions of the specified problemm in terms  of the specified functions which is optimum in the least-squares sense.

Document ID: 3201
Title: Symbolic Manipulation of Poisson Series
Text: Poisson series of three variables are manageable symbolically through as a  set of formal subroutines written partially in the IBM 7094 machine language, but to be called in the FORTRAN language for use in Fortran  programs. An  effort has been made to supply those operations which are most required by celestial mechanics. The routines are entirely self-contained subroutines and require only standard Fortran input/output units 5 and 6; they are design to avoid waste and overflow of core storage space.
Terms: ['', '', '', '', '', '5', '6', '7094', 'a', 'an', 'and', 'and', 'and', 'are', 'are', 'are', 'are', 'as', 'avoid', 'be', 'been', 'but', 'by', 'called', 'celestial', 'core', 'design', 'effort', 'entirely', 'for', 'formal', 'fortran', 'fortran', 'fortran', 'has', 'ibm', 'in', 'in', 'in', 'inputoutput', 'language', 'language', 'machine', 'made', 'manageable', 'mechanics', 'most', 'of', 'of', 'of', 'only', 'operations', 'overflow', 'partially', 'poisson', 'programs', 'require', 'required', 'routines', 'selfcontained', 'series', 'set', 'space', 'standard', 'storage', 'subroutines', 'subroutines', 'supply', 'symbolically', 'the', 'the', 'the', 'they', 'those', 'three', 'through', 'to', 'to', 'to', 'units', 'use', 'variables', 'waste', 'which', 'written']

Document ID: 3202
Title: MANIP: A Computer System for Algebra and Analytic Differentiation
Text: A mathematical expression to be operated upon is written in FORTRAN-like  notation and stored in the computer as a string of BCD characters with all blanks removed. It may be as complicated as desired (parentheses nested without restriction, etc.) so long as the entire expression (or any subsequent form) does not exceed 5000 characters. The problemm of performing algebraic operations and obtaining analytic derivatives was translated into that of identifying and manipulating character sequences. Programs which resulted were written in FORTRAN IV for a CDC 3600 and are discussed in detail.
Terms: ['', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '3600', '5000', 'a', 'a', 'a', 'algebraic', 'all', 'analytic', 'and', 'and', 'and', 'and', 'any', 'are', 'as', 'as', 'as', 'as', 'bcd', 'be', 'be', 'blanks', 'cdc', 'character', 'characters', 'characters', 'complicated', 'computer', 'derivatives', 'desired', 'detail', 'discussed', 'does', 'entire', 'etc', 'exceed', 'expression', 'expression', 'for', 'form', 'fortran', 'fortranlike', 'identifying', 'in', 'in', 'in', 'in', 'into', 'is', 'it', 'iv', 'long', 'manipulating', 'mathematical', 'may', 'nested', 'not', 'notation', 'obtaining', 'of', 'of', 'of', 'operated', 'operations', 'or', 'parentheses', 'performing', 'problemm', 'programs', 'removed', 'restriction', 'resulted', 'sequences', 'so', 'stored', 'string', 'subsequent', 'that', 'the', 'the', 'the', 'to', 'translated', 'upon', 'was', 'were', 'which', 'with', 'without', 'written', 'written']

Document ID: 3203
Title: GRAD Assistant - A Program for Symbolic Algebraic Manipulation and  Differentiation
Text: The General Recursive Algebra and Differentiation Assistant (GRAD Assistant) now under development is a set of LISP functions which symbolically manipulate abd differentiate algebraic expressions. It is designed for use with problemms  in which a large amount of routine manipulation is to be done by a program  without human intervention. Thus, GRAD must recognize necessary simplifications without external guidance. While some complicated expressions (notably ones involving nested radicals and trigonometric functions) do not yield completely to the present version, it has proved quite useful indeed.
Terms: ['', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', 'a', 'a', 'a', 'abd', 'algebra', 'algebraic', 'amount', 'and', 'and', 'assistant', 'assistant', 'be', 'by', 'completely', 'complicated', 'designed', 'development', 'differentiate', 'differentiation', 'do', 'done', 'expressions', 'expressions', 'external', 'for', 'functions', 'functions', 'general', 'grad', 'grad', 'guidance', 'has', 'human', 'in', 'indeed', 'intervention', 'involving', 'is', 'is', 'is', 'it', 'it', 'large', 'lisp', 'manipulate', 'manipulation', 'must', 'necessary', 'nested', 'not', 'notably', 'now', 'of', 'of', 'ones', 'present', 'problemms', 'program', 'proved', 'quite', 'radicals', 'recognize', 'recursive', 'routine', 'set', 'simplifications', 'some', 'symbolically', 'the', 'the', 'thus', 'to', 'to', 'trigonometric', 'under', 'use', 'useful', 'version', 'which', 'which', 'while', 'with', 'without', 'without', 'yield']

Document ID: 3204
Title: An On-Line Program for Non-Numerical Algebra
Text: The goal of this program is to make a step toward te design of an automated mathematical assistant. Some requirements for such a program are: it must be easy to access, and that the result must be obtained in a reasonably short time. Accordingly the program is written for a time-shared computer. The Q-32 computer as System Development Corporation, Santa Monica, California, was  chosen because it also had a LISP 1.5 compiler. Programming and debugging was done from a remote teletype console at Stanford University.
